I'm here to provide some chemical explanation to the reactions in the video.

1. Shells + Muriatic acid (Hydrochloric acid)
CaCO₃ + 2HCl = CaCl₂ + H₂O + CO₂
In this reaction, the Cl⁻ ion is more active than the CO₃²⁻ ion and therefore
replaces it, forming CaCl₂ (Calcium Chloride), which is soluble in water and that's why it "disappears".

2. Shells + Nitric acid
CaCO₃ + 2HNO₃ = Ca(NO₃)₂ + H₂O + CO₂
In this reaction, the NO₃⁻ ion is also more active than the CO₃²⁻ ion and therefore
replaces it, forming Ca(NO₃)₂ (Calcium Nitrate), which , again, is soluble in water and "disappears".

3. Shells + Vinegar (Acetic acid)
CaCO₃ + 2CH₃COOH = Ca(CH₃COO)₂ + H₂O + CO₂
In this reaction, the CH₃COO⁻ ion is more active than the CO₃²⁻ ion (pretty much every anion is more active than the CO₃²⁻ ion) and replaces it, forming Ca(CH₃COO)₂ (Calcium Acetate), which, once again, is soluble in water and "disappears".

4. Shells + Sulfuric acid
CaCO₃ + H₂SO = CaSO₄ + H₂O + CO₂
In this reaction, the SO₄²⁻ ion is more active than the CO₃²⁻ ion and
replaces it, forming CaSO₄ (Calcium Sulfate, or more commonly known as plaster), which is not fully
soluble in water.

5. "Cooking" shells
CaCO₃ + Heat = CaO + CO₂
When heating CaCO₃, a bond is weakened, splitting the compound into CO₂ and CaO (commonly known as quicklime or burnt lime)

6. Cooked shells (CaO) + Water
CaO + H₂O = Ca(OH)₂

Combining burnt lime with water produces Ca(OH) (also known as slaked lime), which is actually a base, but it is not fully soluble in water (and that's why they didn't hurt their hands when touching it - because it didn't have time to fully dissolve in the water, and therefore the solution was still very weakly basic).

Why sulfuric acid was different: When an acid reacts with calcium carbonate, the anion of the acid replaces the carbonate anion. So calcium carbonate becomes calcium sulfate. And calcium sulfate is not very soluble, so it stays in place and forms a barrier to further reaction. The other resultants: calcium nitrate, calcium chloride, and calcium acetate are much more soluble, so the reaction will continue.

CaCl2 is soluble in water (so the shell is still there, but it’s mostly in the form of Ca2+ ions!) and the bubbles that form are from the decomposition of the H2CO3 into CO2 and water vapor. The reason the sulfuric acid didn’t react was because CaSO4, the potential product, is only sparingly soluble in water. The vinegar (acetic acid) reacted much slower due to the fact that acetic acid is a weak acid, and also the concentration was relatively low. It was likely a limiting reactant in that respect.

First up lemme say how much I love TKOR for the funky science experiments... Been following for a long time.. But sulfuric acid for "dissolving" CaCO3 guys? Seriously? High school kids know that the dissolution occurred because of a double displacement reaction. CaCO3 + HA = CaA2 + CO2 (hence the bubbles) + H2O. If the calcium salt formed itself is insoluble in water, it will not be solvated for the transition state to decompose into the product. And with sulfuric acid CaCO3 gives CaSO4 AKA gypsum. Hence no reaction.
Also, putting the shells in the furnace decomposed CaCO3 to CaO, whose dissolution is exothermic and gives Ca(OH)2. Get your chem right before you start guys... Especially, considering the kind of stuff you are doing, reading about it might be the difference between you going home in pieces or in a single piece. Cheerio!

Nice video! The reaction taking place is mainly calcium carbonate (CaCO_3) with acid (H^+, and some anion) to form dissolved calcium (Ca^2+) and carbonic acid H_2CO_3, which decomposes right away to water and carbon dioxide. The severity of the reaction mainly depends on how much H^+ is around, aka the acid strength. As Calli pointed out, the nitric is 70%, which is 16 molar (to compare apples with apples). The sulfuric was only 2 molar, or only about 11%, and hence much less reactive. Along the same lines, 5% acetic acid is 0.8 molar and on top of that a weak acid whereas the others are all strong acids. Nice demo, though! (^= superscript, _= subscript)

You touched on it in the video, that roasting calcium carbonate at that high temperature basically makes quicklime (calcium oxide). When you dissolve it in water, you're making calcium hydroxide, which is a pretty potent base (depending on the concentration). That's actually the reason for the peeling/flaking that Calli pointed out - the exterior oxidizes in layers, which peel off, exposing the fresh shell material underneath to the air in the furnace, in turn forming another layer of calcium oxide. It's essentially behaving the same as scale that forms on forged metal, since it is essentially forming a metal oxide.


As far as the shells not reacting with bases, carbonates in general are considered moderately strong bases so they wouldn't necessarily react with other bases in any meaningful way.


Lastly, the blue color that you started seeing in some of those shells you were dissolving in nitric acid were probably different metal nitrates formed by the nitric acid oxidizing trace minerals present in the shell/pigments.

The seashells are composed of CALCIUM CARBONATE, and the experience of burn into a furnace the seashells it results into a powder known as CALCIUM OXIDE (CaO - AKA "Virgin Lime") that is higly caustic/alkaline.

After hidratate with water, You obtain the CALDIUM HIDROXIDE (Ca(OH)2 - AKA "Hidratated Lime).

Both process is used to obtain construction/paint lime and when You do the same with Calcite (limestone) or Dolomite rocks, that consists into burn the rock at high temperatures, and trows water when its HOT, or, hidratate when is cold, but the first method is more usual, due to necessity to hidratate the CaO before use it, avoiding SKIN BURNING and ACRYLIC/PVA PAINT "explodes" (crackeling and bubbles out) after finishing of construction.

After the Ca(OH)2 receives the water one SECOND TIME , it needs to LOOSE this water to reverse the process, called RECARBONATATION, where the CALCIUM HIDROXIDE volta again a um "estado rochoso" after LOOSES this water and receives CO2 from the AIR.

A quick tip, nitric acid can react with Nitrile gloves (the black gloves you are using).  If any were to get on the gloves it is best to take them off immediately.  Azeotropic nitric (70ish%) doesn't react as fast as fuming nitric (80% and up), but it will still react.  Fuming nitric will set them on fire.  Butyl rubber gloves would be better, or work with it bare handed like I do.
